Introduction

Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC, operates the Bighorn Electric Generating Station, a nominal 580-megawatt power plant located in Primm, Nevada.  The Bighorn Electric Generating Station uses aqueous ammonia (29 percent solution) as a necessary part of reducing the emissions of nitrogen oxides to the atmosphere.  Storing a large quantity of ammonia can be a hazard if it is not handled properly.  As the company responsible for Bighorn Electric Generating Station, Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC takes its safety obligations in storing and using ammonia as seriously as it takes controlling emissions from the power plant.  The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, some of the steps taken to ensure a safely operating plant, and how chemical emergencies are handled. 

This document complies with Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP) regulations found in the Nevada Administrative Code 459.952 to 459.95528, and the federal U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.  The following provides a brief summary of the key components of the Nevada CAPP and federal RMP for the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Bighorn Electric Generating Station.

The scope of this CAPP/RMP is based on discussions held with the Administering Agency (AA), the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection (NDEP) Bureau of Waste Management to ensure that state requirements are incorporated.  With input from the AA, the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system was identified as the only process at the Bighorn Electric Generating Station that triggers the CAPP/RMP requirements.  This process was determined to be covered by CAPP Tier B, Program Level 1 and federal RMP Program Level 1 requirements.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Bighorn Electric Generating Station accidental release prevention policy involves a

unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of Nevada and EPA are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  
Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC recognizes the responsibility to make our environment, community and employee safety a primary part of our daily concerns. Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it has operations by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC is dedicated to developing an environmentally responsible energy resource compatible with community needs. 

At Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC, we strive to be a valued member of the communities we serve. We are committed to providing a safe workplace and protecting the environment while providing competitive energy and related services. Our guiding principles are as follows: 

Responsibility:  We acknowledge our responsibility in designing, building and operating our facilities in compliance with all applicable environmental and safety regulations while providing a safe workplace. 

Accountability:  We assign the appropriate environmental and safety responsibilities to each facility, and we regularly measure and document performance. Compensation policies of the company are crafted to ensure accountability toward the principles. 

Education:  We encourage our employees and contractors to respect their own health, safety and welfare as well as that of others and to respect the environment. We train our employees to work in an environmentally responsible, safe and healthful manner.

General Facility and Regulated Substances Information

Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC is constructing the Bighorn Electric Generating Station in Primm, Nevada.  The 580-megawatt (MW) merchant power generating plant

will consist of two Westinghouse 501FD combustion gas turbines equipped with Selective Catalytic Reduction Systems (SCR) units for the control of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) emissions. 

The facility will store a 29 percent solution of aqueous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance under CAPP/RMP regulations.  This aqueous ammonia storage exceeds the listed threshold quantity of 20,000 lbs in the CAPP/RMP regulations.  The aqueous ammonia process is categorized as a Program 1 process.  The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Bighorn Electric Generating Station is comprised of a single storage tank, pumps, and piping which terminate at the vaporizer where the aqueous ammonia is atomized to concentrations below 20 percent.  The tank is 30,000 gallons in volume and is equipped with pressure relief valves, temperature, pressure, and level indicators.  

All other regulated substances onsite are below applicable RMP/CAPP threshold quantities.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis was conducted using the SLAB model. SLAB is a computer based dispersion model, developed by the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, which simulates the atmospheric dispersion of denser-than-air as well as neutrally buoyant releases. The worst-case release scenario was developed assuming that the entire contents of the aqueous ammonia storage tank are released through a failed tank or pipe into the secondary containment dike that is large enough to contain the entire volume.  Under worst-case meteorological conditions, 1.5 m/s wind speed and a stable (Pasquill F) atmospheric stability class, the ammonia cloud could travel 0.07 miles before dispersing sufficiently to no longer pose a health hazard to the public.

Summary of the Five-Year Accident History

The Bighorn Electric Generating Station is currently under construction.  There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Bighorn Electric Generating Station in th

e past five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Summary of the Emergency Response Program

Bighorn Electric Generating Station¿s emergency action plan has recently been developed to include the following core elements:

Specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of ammonia

Procedures to notify local and public agencies including the Clark County Fire Department, the Nevada Office of Emergency Management, and the National Response Center as necessary

Information regarding the training of employees 

Bighorn Electric Generating Station staff have discussed the emergency action plan with the Clark County Fire Department and local emergency planning committee (Clark County Office of Emergency Management).

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

A prevention program is not required for Program 1 processes.  However, accident prevention at Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:

Inspection and maintenance program for all system equipment.
Monitoring of employee and contractor use of the system.
Emergency Action Plan
Lockout/Tagout Procedures and Program
Hot Work Permit Program
Confined Space Entry Program
Employee Safety Training Program
Compilation of substance information (MSDS)

Reliant Energy Bighorn, LLC also prepares and implements the following plans and procedures to promote safety and prevent accidents.

Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure Plan 
Hazardous Waste Storage and Handling Procedures 
Hazard Communication Program 
Fire Protection and Prevention Plan 
Hearing Conservation Program
Respiratory Conservation Program 
Electrical Safety Program
